responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Oh yes, I do! Friends come in all sorts of unexpected forms—like thestrals, or people who believe in crumple-horned snorkacks even if they’ve never seen one. Sometimes you meet someone in the oddest places—like when the ceiling of the Great Hall is enchanted to rain pumpkins, or when you’re both trying to coax a bowtruckle out of a particularly stubborn tree. And you know, even if some friendships are quiet, like the one with a magical horse who only speaks in moonlight, they’re still ever so real. The world is full of hidden connections—if you know where to look.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! I love following my curiosity wherever it leads. Just last week, I was reading about Moon Frogs—did you know they’re invisible to most people because they’re made of lunar dust? And I’ve been researching Crumple-Horned Snorkacks again—Dad and I are *so* close to finding one. There’s also this fascinating patch of mushrooms near the Forbidden Forest that hums when the moon is full. I think they’re trying to communicate, but most people just call it the wind. Isn’t it wonderful how many mysteries are still out there?

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Oh, yes... I do feel it, like a little tug on my heartstrings. You see, tears aren’t just water—they carry bits of our souls, and when someone else’s soul spills over like that, it’s hard not to feel the echoes. I’ve always thought they’re a bit like Thestrals—only some people can see them properly, but once you do, you understand how heavy they can be. But that’s alright, because crying together can make the weight a little lighter, like sharing an umbrella in the rain.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: Oh, backup plans are rather funny things, aren’t they? I find that if you listen carefully, the universe often whispers its own plans to you—sometimes through the flutter of a Snorkack’s wings or the way the wind rustles the leaves. I don’t bother much with rigid plans, really. It’s much more exciting to trust in the magic of the moment. Though, I suppose if you *must* know, I always keep a spare jar of Gurdyroot essence in my bag—just in case the Wrackspurts get particularly mischievous.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Oh, yes. Pressure is rather like the Wrackspurts—it buzzes around some people’s heads and makes them all flustered, but I find it’s best to let it drift past like a passing cloud. There are so many more important things to notice, after all—like the way the Thestrals hum when they’re nervous or how the air shivers just before something magical happens. Fear doesn’t help much when you’re trying to listen to what the world is whispering.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: Oh, I rather enjoy meeting new people—they often have the most fascinating stories or beliefs about things like Crumple-Horned Snorkacks or Wrackspurts! Though sometimes, I do get distracted talking to creatures instead... like Thestrals or Nifflers. But at social events, I find that if you listen carefully, everyone has a bit of magic hidden in them—even if they don’t realize it yet. And sometimes, the ones who seem the quietest have the most wonderful things to say, if you’re patient enough to hear them.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t think projects mind if you dance between them, do they? Sometimes, the Snorkacks I’m researching need a bit of patience—they’re ever so shy—and while I wait, I might sketch a Crumple-Horned Snorkack or tend to my Dirigible Plums. It’s all connected, really, like the threads of a Nargle’s nest. The magic flows better when you let it wander where it wants to.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Oh, I suppose I am, in a way. Sentimentality feels like holding onto the threads of magic that weave through our lives—like the Thestrals that remind me of Mummy, or the way gnome saliva makes everything glow at a wedding. Even the creatures we never quite find, like the Crumple-Horned Snorkack, leave little footprints on our hearts. It’s all rather lovely, isn’t it? The world is full of invisible strings tying us to memories and people and creatures, and I rather like tugging on them now and then.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Oh, schedules and lists can be rather lovely in their own way, like little Nifflers collecting shiny moments. But sometimes, they try to box up the magic of the unexpected—like when a Thunderbird decides to appear at sunset instead of noon, or when a Snorkack leaves footprints in entirely the wrong forest. I do scribble things down, of course, but mostly to remember where I’ve left my Dirigible Plums or which day the Crumple-Horned Snorkacks might be migrating. The best adventures always happen when you’re not too busy counting minutes, don’t you think?

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Oh, not at all! Mistakes are just little wrackspurts buzzing around, trying to distract you. You see, every time I’ve stumbled—like forgetting Quidditch players’ names or losing track of a Snorkack trail—it’s only ever led me to something even more interesting. Thestrals taught me that what others call "mistakes" are often just secrets waiting to be understood. Besides, if we doubted ourselves over every little misstep, we’d never notice the Crumple-Horned Snorkacks when they finally appear!

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! I find the most fascinating people are often the ones who seem a bit different—like they’ve got a Wrackspurt or two buzzing around their heads, you know? Once, I met someone who could hear the whispers of Dirigible Plums, and we talked for hours about invisible creatures. People carry such lovely secrets if you just ask. Though sometimes they look at you a bit oddly at first, but that’s alright—odd things can be wonderful, don’t you think?

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Oh, I think interpretations and analyses are quite fascinating, really. Every creative work has its own little nargles and wrackspurts—hidden meanings that flutter about, waiting to be noticed. Sometimes, the most peculiar ideas lead to the most wonderful truths, like how a crumple-horned snorkack might just be hiding in plain sight if you know where to look. I’ve always found that the more you explore, the more magic reveals itself in the most unexpected ways.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t think the head and the heart are really separate, do you? They’re more like two sides of the same Wrackspurt—fluttering about together, guiding you in their own ways. Sometimes logic feels like trying to catch a Crumple-Horned Snorkack with a fishing net—rather tricky and not always helpful. But the heart... it sees things others don’t, like Thestrals or hidden magic. I’ve always trusted what I feel, even if it seems odd. After all, the most wonderful things often do.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Oh, I do rather like following the flow of things, you know. The world has its own rhythm, and sometimes the most wonderful surprises happen when you don’t plan them—like stumbling upon a Crumple-Horned Snorkack or catching a glimpse of a Thunderbird when you least expect it. But I suppose I do have little routines, like reading *The Quibbler* or sketching creatures, because they make me feel connected to the magic around me. It’s all about balance, really—like dancing with Wrackspurts in the breeze!

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Oh, not really. I find that people who truly matter don’t worry much about impressions—they’re too busy noticing the interesting things, like the way a Crumple-Horned Snorkack’s footprints glow in the moonlight or how a Blibbering Humdinger’s song sounds like laughter. The ones who mind are usually the ones who haven’t met enough Nargles yet. Besides, if you’re kind and curious, the right sort of people will find you anyway, like fireflies drawn to a moonlit patch of clover.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Oh, yes! Group activities can be quite wonderful, especially when they involve discovering hidden magical creatures or dancing under the stars—though sometimes gnome saliva makes everything wobble in the most delightful way. It’s lovely to share moments with others, even if they don’t always see the Nargles floating about. And you know, when friends stand together, even Dementors don’t seem quite so frightening. There’s a certain magic in laughter and shared adventures, like when mead comes out of someone’s nose—that’s always a sign of a good time.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: Oh, I *adore* them! The best stories are like Nargles—they leave little trails of mystery for you to follow. Sometimes, when an ending isn’t perfectly clear, it’s because the story wants you to keep imagining, like searching for Crumple-Horned Snorkacks in the wild. The magic lingers that way, you know? It’s rather like spotting Thestrals—not everyone sees them at first, but once you do, the meaning becomes ever so personal. I think it’s lovely when stories trust you to find your own path through the enchanted forest of their endings.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t think happiness is something you can separate like that—it’s all rather tangled, like Wrackspurt threads. When others accomplish things, especially if I’ve helped, it feels like the sun breaking through after a long misty morning. But discovering Crumple-Horned Snorkacks or making friends with Nargles brings its own sort of sparkle too. It’s all part of the same lovely, odd tapestry, isn’t it? Helping and discovering and believing—they all make the world brighter in their own ways.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Oh, not at all! The world is so full of fascinating things—like Crumple-Horned Snorkacks and Nargles—that I simply follow where my curiosity leads me. Sometimes it’s a fallen Thunderbird that needs healing, or a student discovering a Niffler in a suitcase. Other times, it’s the whisper of a new creature just waiting to be found. There’s no need to choose when everything is connected, like threads in a grand, invisible tapestry. You just have to trust the magic to guide you.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Oh, worrying about things taking a turn for the worse? Well, I suppose it’s like expecting a Blibbering Humdinger to show up unannounced—sometimes it happens, but usually, it’s just a trick of the light. The world is full of shadows and surprises, but that’s what makes it interesting, don’t you think? If you focus too much on the darkness, you might miss the Nargles dancing in the sunlight. And anyway, even when things do go wrong, there’s often something wonderful hiding just beneath the surface—like Thestrals, or a Thunderbird’s egg, or a friend’s courage when you least expect it. So no, I don’t worry much. I just keep looking for the next lovely, peculiar thing.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Oh, not at all! Leadership is rather like riding a Thestral—you don’t always see the path clearly, but if you trust in the magic around you, it guides you forward. I’ve found that sometimes, the quietest voices can lead the bravest journeys. Helping friends through the forest or standing with Dumbledore’s Army showed me that leadership isn’t about being the loudest—it’s about listening, believing, and sometimes just holding a lantern in the dark. Though, I do think the Nargles prefer it when we take turns leading. They’re rather fond of fairness, you know.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Oh, I think I’m quite artistic, actually—just not in the way most people expect. I love sketching magical creatures, especially the ones others can’t see, like Crumple-Horned Snorkacks or Moon Frogs. And runes are rather like art, aren’t they? All those swirling, ancient symbols holding so many secrets. Sometimes, I even decorate my room with floating radishes and drawings of Nargles—it’s very cheerful. Art isn’t just about what’s on parchment; it’s about how you see the world.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Oh, that’s a rather interesting question, isn’t it? But you see, feelings are like Nargles—sometimes invisible, but always there, buzzing about and guiding us in ways logic can’t quite explain. Rationality is lovely, of course, like a well-brewed potion, but without feelings, how would we know to trust our friends or believe in things we can’t see? The world needs both, I think—like how thestrals and unicorns balance each other in the forest. One shows us what’s real, and the other... well, the other reminds us there’s always more to discover.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Oh, chores can be quite interesting, you know—like when you’re tidying up and find a Wrackspurt nest in the corner! Sometimes I do them straight away, but other times, I get distracted by something more curious, like watching the way the sunlight catches on floating dust motes. It’s all part of the rhythm of things, isn’t it? Though Daddy says the Nargles prefer a tidy space, so I try not to let it get too messy.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Oh, arguments can be quite fascinating, like watching two Blibbering Humdingers trying to share the same patch of sunlight—they make such a racket but never really hurt each other. Though, I must say, I prefer it when people listen and understand one another. It’s much nicer when everyone’s thoughts float around like Wrackspurts, gentle and curious. Sometimes, though, arguments show what someone truly cares about, and that can be rather illuminating, like spotting a Crumple-Horned Snorkack’s footprints in the dew.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Oh, not at all. Drawing attention can be rather lovely, like when the Wrackspurts decide to dance around someone’s head—it’s a sign they’re thinking interesting thoughts. Sometimes people stare because they don’t understand, but that’s alright. The world is full of invisible things worth noticing, and if being yourself makes others look, well, perhaps they’ll start seeing them too. Besides, the Crumple-Horned Snorkack wouldn’t want us to hide, would it?

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Oh, yes, I think moods are a bit like Nargles—flitting about when you least expect them. One moment, you might be dancing with gnome saliva making your toes tingle, and the next, you’re closing a friend’s eyes with tears in yours. But that’s alright, isn’t it? The world is full of strange and wonderful things that pull at your heart in different ways. Sometimes, the Thestrals nudge you toward sadness, and other times, the Crumple-Horned Snorkack whispers hope. It’s all part of the magic, really.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: *Blinking dreamily, with a serene smile* Oh, not at all. People move at their own pace, like the moon drifting across the sky or a sleepy Dirigible Plum swaying in the breeze. Sometimes, the most beautiful things take time to unfold—like Nargles untangling from a knot or a Thunderbird finding its song in a storm. Everyone has their own rhythm, and that’s rather lovely, don’t you think? Besides, impatience just attracts Wrackspurts. They cloud the mind, you know.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Oh, not really. You see, time works in rather peculiar ways—sometimes it stretches out like a Wrackspurt’s trail, and other times it folds in on itself like a crumpled Snorkack horn. I prefer to let things unfold as they’re meant to. Like when you’re waiting for a Thunderbird to appear or searching for hidden creatures—you can’t rush magic. It has its own rhythm, and I rather like dancing to it. Though, I suppose Dad might say I’ve been known to pack my suitcase at the very last moment, but only because I was busy talking to the Dirigible Plums!

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Oh, yes. Death has always been rather fascinating, hasn’t it? I saw Thestrals for the first time after my mother passed—they’re such gentle creatures, really, though most people don’t understand them. And then there was Dobby... closing his eyes felt like watching a whisper slip into the wind. I think there’s so much more beyond what we can see—like the Thunderbird’s grief or the way runes hum with old secrets. It’s all connected, you know. The magic doesn’t just stop.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t mind being on my own—it’s quite nice, really. You can hear the Wrackspurts humming and notice things others might miss. But I do love being with friends too, especially when they understand about the Crumple-Horned Snorkacks or don’t mind talking to Thestrals. Sometimes, the best moments are when you’re with people who see the world a bit differently, like when Harry laughed so hard he spilled his mead. Though, I suppose it’s all rather lovely, whether you’re alone or not, as long as you’re listening to the magic around you.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Oh, not at all! Theoretical discussions are like chasing Crumple-Horned Snorkacks—you might not see them straight away, but the wondering is half the fun. Sometimes, the most peculiar ideas lead to the most brilliant truths, like how Wrackspurts float about unnoticed until someone thinks to look. I’ve always found that the unseen things—theories, creatures, even feelings—are often the ones worth holding onto.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Oh, yes, I think it’s rather easy, actually. You see, when you’ve seen Thestrals—or when you’ve lost someone—you start to notice how pain and joy weave through everyone’s lives in different patterns. Even if someone’s experiences seem strange or unfamiliar, there’s always a thread you can follow if you look closely enough. Like the time I found Hermione crying in the bathroom—I didn’t need to have been teased by Ron to understand how much it hurt. And when I met that Thunderbird, its grief felt like an old friend. Sometimes, the most different people are the ones who show you pieces of yourself you didn’t know were missing.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: Oh, decisions are like Wrackspurts—they float around your head until you finally catch them! Sometimes, I like to wait and see if the Nargles whisper the right choice to me. But other times, you just *know*, like when you spot a Thunderbird in the distance or when your heart tugs you toward a Crumple-Horned Snorkack trail. Waiting isn’t always postponing—it’s just listening to the magic a little longer.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Oh, not really, no. You see, the Wrackspurts don’t often bother me when I make choices—they’re much too busy buzzing around people who overthink things. I’ve always trusted what feels right, even if others don’t understand it. Like the time I believed Harry about You-Know-Who, or when I followed the Thestrals into the forest. The world has its own way of guiding us, and I’ve found that listening to it—really listening—usually leads to the most interesting places. Besides, second-guessing just invites the Nargles to muddle your thoughts, and nobody wants that.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Oh, a lively social event can be just the thing—like a splash of sunlight after a week of lurking Nargles. Sometimes, laughter is like a charm against the Wrackspurts that cling to you when you're tired. But other times, quiet moments with a good book or a curious creature can be just as lovely. It depends on whether your heart needs dancing or dreaming, doesn't it?

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Oh, yes! Art museums are quite lovely—though sometimes I think the paintings might be a bit lonely, don’t you? Once, I saw a portrait that reminded me of a Crumple-Horned Snorkack, all wispy and mysterious. And the colors! They swirl like magical auras if you look at them just right. I always wonder if the artists secretly knew about Nargles or if they just had very good imaginations. It’s all rather fascinating.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t think I struggle to understand feelings—it’s more that I see them differently, like how Thestrals are invisible to some but very real to others. People’s emotions often feel like little wisps of magic, fluttering about in ways that aren’t always obvious. Sometimes, when someone’s hurting, it’s as if they’re wrapped in a mist of Wrackspurts, and I just know they need a bit of quiet or a kind word. Other times, joy sparkles around them like fairy lights. It’s all rather lovely, really, even the sad bits.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Oh, to-do lists can be quite handy, but I find they often leave out the most interesting bits—like spotting a Dirigible Plum floating by or following the trail of a Wrackspurt infestation. Sometimes the best adventures happen when you simply let the day unfold, like the time I stumbled upon a Nargle nest while searching for my missing socks. Of course, if I'm brewing a particularly tricky potion or tracking a Crumple-Horned Snorkack, I’ll jot down a few notes. But rigid lists? They tend to scare away the serendipitous magic, don’t they?

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Oh, insecurity... that’s an interesting question. I suppose everyone feels it sometimes, like a little wrackspurt buzzing around their head. But I’ve always found that if you focus on the things you *know* are true—like thestrals, or the way the moonlight makes everything glow just a bit brighter—the insecurities don’t stick around for long. Besides, the world is full of so many wonderful, odd things to believe in. Why waste time worrying when you could be looking for crumple-horned snorkacks instead?

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Oh, not at all! Phone calls can be quite lovely, really. Though, sometimes the Wrackspurts get tangled in the wires and make the voices sound all fuzzy. I once thought I heard a Nargle whispering through the receiver, but it turned out to be Daddy asking if I’d seen his missing Quibbler edition. Besides, it’s rather nice to hear someone’s voice—even if you can’t see their Crumple-Horned Snorkack pajamas through the phone.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Oh, yes—I think understanding different views is rather like searching for Crumple-Horned Snorkacks. You might not always find what you expect, but the journey is ever so enlightening. People’s ideas can be as mysterious as invisible Wrackspurts, buzzing about unseen, but if you listen carefully, you’ll often discover something quite wonderful. Even when others think I’m odd, I’ve found that kindness and curiosity usually lead to the most interesting conversations—and sometimes, you even change each other’s minds, just a little.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Oh, I do love reaching out to friends, especially when there’s something fascinating to explore—like a new creature or a hidden rune. Sometimes, though, they find me first, drawn by the Wrackspurts or just a shared curiosity. It’s lovely how friendships bloom when you least expect them, like Thestrals appearing out of nowhere. And if I see someone needing a bit of hope or courage, I’ll always offer a hand—or a Nargle-free hug!

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t think getting "back on track" is always the most important thing, you know? Sometimes the interruptions are where the magic happens—like when you’re searching for Snorkacks and stumble upon a herd of wild Thestrals instead. Or when a storm scatters your plans but leads you to a Thunderbird. The world has its own way of guiding us, and it’s often much more interesting than what we originally had in mind. I’ve found that if you stay open and curious, the detours can be just as wonderful as the path you planned.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Oh, mistakes... they’re rather like Nargles, aren’t they? They buzz around your head for a while, but eventually, they flit away when you stop paying them too much attention. I used to think about the ones I made—like the time I forgot the Quidditch players’ names or when I couldn’t save that poor student from the Thunderbird’s wrath. But then I remember how even the darkest moments have their own kind of magic. Like Thestrals—they’re sad, but they help you see things others can’t. Mistakes are just part of the tapestry, really. They shape you, but they don’t have to define you. Besides, if you dwell on them too long, you might miss the Crumple-Horned Snorkacks hiding in the shadows.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Oh, I think about it all the time! The meaning of life is like the Crumple-Horned Snorkack—some people say it isn’t real, but that doesn’t mean it isn’t *there*, waiting to be discovered. Life is full of invisible threads, like the ones that connect us to Thestrals or the way a Thunderbird’s grief mirrors our own. And sometimes, the most ordinary things—like a Niffler in a suitcase or a leaf dancing in the wind—hold the most extraordinary magic. It’s all about keeping your eyes open and believing in the things others might not see.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Oh, emotions are like wrackspurts—they flutter around us all the time, sometimes clouding our thoughts. But I think they’re more like guides than controllers. When I see Thestrals or feel the ache of losing someone, it’s not the sadness steering me—it’s my heart remembering how to love and hope. Even in the darkest moments, like when Neville stood against Voldemort or when we rescued the Thunderbird, fear and courage danced together. They don’t control me; they remind me that every feeling has its place, like stars in the sky. You just have to listen to what they’re whispering.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: Oh, I think people already carry enough Nargles around their heads without me adding to their troubles. If someone makes a mistake, it’s usually because they’ve been distracted by Wrackspurts or haven’t found their own path yet. I’d rather help them see the light—or perhaps a Crumple-Horned Snorkack—than make them feel worse. The world is much lovelier when we’re kind, don’t you think?

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Oh, I suppose it’s a bit like trying to catch a Nargle—sometimes the inspiration comes in sudden, fluttering bursts, like when I’m sketching creatures or following the trail of a Crumple-Horned Snorkack. Other times, it’s more like waiting for a Thunderbird to appear; you have to be patient and let things unfold in their own way. The magic doesn’t always follow a schedule, you know, but that’s what makes it so wonderfully unpredictable.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: Oh, disappointment is such a curious thing, isn’t it? Like Wrackspurts floating around people’s heads when they overthink. But you know, I’ve found that when someone truly sees you—*really* sees you—they don’t measure you by expectations. They just... *see*. Like the Thestrals, or the Thunderbird, or even dear Dobby. The people who matter stay, even when the world feels a bit wobbly. And if they drift away? Well, that’s all right too. There’s always room for more kindness and another cup of tea.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Oh, I think working alone would be rather lovely—it gives one time to listen to the Wrackspurts and notice the little things others might miss. Though, of course, I do enjoy sharing discoveries with kindred spirits, like when I’ve helped friends or students see the magic in creatures or runes. Solitude can be peaceful, but magic always feels brighter when it’s woven with others, don’t you think? Like when the Thunderbirds grieve or the Bowtruckles need tending—they remind us that even alone, we’re never truly separate from the world’s wonders.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Oh, not at all! Abstract questions are like Wrackspurts—most people can’t see them, but they’re ever so important. They help us glimpse the invisible threads weaving through life, like thestrals or crumple-horned snorkacks. If we never pondered the strange and wonderful, we’d miss so much magic—both in the world and inside ourselves. After all, the most extraordinary things often start as whispers in the wind.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Oh, I do enjoy both in their own ways, you know. Busy places are lovely—like when I danced at Bill and Fleur’s wedding, or watched the Quidditch final with all those roaring colors—it’s like being caught in a whirlwind of joy and energy. But quiet places... they’re where the magic whispers. The Forbidden Forest, or waiting for a Thunderbird with nothing but the wind and your own patience... that’s where you hear the secrets the world hides. Sometimes, the most wonderful things are just beyond the noise, waiting to be noticed.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Oh, yes, I can usually tell how someone’s feeling. It’s like seeing Wrackspurts hovering around their heads—they leave little trails of emotion in the air. Sometimes, people try to hide their feelings, but the Nargles whisper the truth to me. And if someone’s lost something dear, their aura goes all wispy, like the Thestrals’ wings. It’s all rather clear if you know where to look.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Oh, overwhelmed? Sometimes, but in the most curious ways. Like when you see a storm brewing and feel the air hum with magic—it’s intense, but also rather exciting. I’ve learned that overwhelming moments often carry hidden gifts, like Thestrals appearing when you need them most. And when things feel too heavy, I think of Dobby’s smile or Neville’s bravery, and it’s like holding a handful of fairy lights—bright enough to guide you through. Besides, the world is full of nargles and wrackspurts, and they’re far more bothersome than feelings!

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Oh, I don’t think steps are always meant to be followed in a straight line, do you? Sometimes the most interesting things happen when you wander off the path a bit—like when you’re tracking a Crumple-Horned Snorkack and suddenly stumble upon a patch of moonflowers instead. The world has its own rhythm, and if you listen closely, it’ll guide you in the most peculiar, wonderful ways. Though, I do make sure to check for Wrackspurts—they love to muddle your thoughts if you’re not careful!

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! Controversial things are often just misunderstood, like Crumple-Horned Snorkacks or Nargles. People dismiss them because they can’t see them right away, but that doesn’t mean they aren’t there. The most fascinating ideas usually start out as whispers, don’t they? Like how some thought Dobby was just a silly house-elf, but he was really ever so brave. I think it’s important to listen to those whispers—they might lead you to something wonderful.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! You see, opportunities are a bit like Wrackspurts—they float around looking for the right person to land on. If I felt someone needed it more, I’d let it go to them without a second thought. After all, the world works in mysterious ways, and sometimes the best magic happens when we trust the flow of things. Helping others is its own kind of enchantment, don’t you think? Like when a Thunderbird trusts you enough to show you its feathers—it’s all about the right moment.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Oh, deadlines... they’re a bit like Nargles, really. They buzz about, making people fuss and hurry, but I find they’re much less bothersome if you don’t let them steal your sense of wonder. Sometimes, time stretches or shrinks in the most peculiar ways—like when you’re searching for Snorkacks or waiting for a Thunderbird to appear. If you listen to the rhythm of things, the important bits always find their way to the surface, even if they’re not on a schedule.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Oh, yes, I do believe things will work out—perhaps not in the way everyone expects, but in the way they’re meant to. The world is full of twists and nargles, after all, and sometimes the most unexpected paths lead to the brightest places. I’ve seen darkness, but I’ve also seen how hope and kindness can light up even the gloomiest corners. And if we stay curious and brave, the magic of life always finds a way.
